subject: Re: [junit] Re: A method for estimating number of junit test cases	using Cyclomatic complexi
msgSnippet: ... Along these lines... When a bug is found first write a test that captures the bug behavior, then fix the code.  That may be a significant investment,
messageBody:
On Fri, 2003-08-08 at 11:58, Dave Astels wrote:
> --- In junit@yahoogroups.com, "Selvakumar Ganesan"
> <selvakumar.ganesan@w...> wrote:
> > Hi,
> > I am trying to estimate effort for writing a regression test suite
> > based on Junit for an existing system.
>
> Our approach/view is that you do not want to strive to build a fully
> comprehensive test suite from the beginning.. for just the reason you
> discovered.. it's a BIG time investment. What you want to do is
> maximize the ROI of the time spent writing tests (i.e. get the biggest
> bang for the buck). You need to find places in the codebase that
> would benefit the most from adding tests and go after those first.
> You just keep plugging away at it.. What's the worst problem? Deal
> with it. Now what's the worst problem. Deal with it.. etc. Also,
> when you work on a piece of code, wrap it in some tests first. As you
> have more & more tests in place, you'll be better able to refactor
> into something that is more testable.. so you can add more & better
> tests. Getting a legacy codebase under test (and under control!)
> isn't a big bang effort... it's gradual... part of everyone's daily work.

Along these lines... When a bug is found first write a test that
captures the bug behavior, then fix the code. That may be a significant
investment, depending on the complexity of the bug. But, it will be
well worth it to have the TestFixture that catches it to make sure it
doesn't happen again.

Although I agree with Dave (above) I will say this about the metrics
themselves, I think 2 hours is pretty high, especially if the code is at
a reasonably well-factored state (which it may not be, unless you had
*_really_* disciplined developers). Even if it isn't at that state, I
still think two hours as the average is too high. I would estimate .75
hours max as the average which would put you at 6567.75 hours (approx.
821 person days).

=jason
